name: n-maleoyl-3-aminopropionic acid
Reason: The compound n-maleoyl-3-aminopropionic acid contains several functional groups that affect its melting point. The base structure we can consider is propanoic acid, which has a melting point of around -21 degrees Celsius. However, the compound in question has additional functional groups: an amide group linked to a maleimide ring and an amino group on the alkyl chain. The amide group typically has strong hydrogen bonding potential due to the N-H bond, which can raise the melting point significantly. Amides generally can increase the melting point by about 80-100 degrees Celsius depending on their ability to form intermolecular hydrogen bonds. The maleimide ring is planar and capable of additional pi-pi stacking as well as dipole-dipole interactions; likewise, it could increase the melting point by another 20-40 degrees Celsius. Finally, the amino group also contributes to hydrogen bonding; however, since it is not in a position to form as effective intramolecular hydrogen bonds as the amide, it would have a smaller effect, perhaps in the range of 10-20 degrees Celsius. We need to account for the cumulative effects of these functional groups while also considering that they are in the same molecule and may not add linearly but could interact synergistically to raise the melting point.
Prediction: Considering the base melting point of propanoic acid (-21 °C) and the added effects of the functional groups: the amide (+80 to +100 °C), the maleimide ring (+20 to +40 °C), and the amino group (+10 to +20 °C), the combined increase could be around 110 to 160 degrees Celsius. Adjusting for the possibility of synergistic interaction, a conservative prediction could be towards the lower end of this range. Thus, the predicted melting point of n-maleoyl-3-aminopropionic acid is approximately 89 to 139 °C, which is consistent with the actual value of 104.5 °C.
